moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6
comment: I haven't seen this opening variation played by the top GMs in recent months. I suppose it was worn out and they needed to play something else, but there may have been a concensus that it was getting too easy for White to gain and keep the advantage.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5
comment: Richter

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6
comment: Black sometime s uses ...g7-g5 to help fight for control of the dark squares, in lieu of having a Pe5 to do that.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4
comment: When I first saw this variation I was skeptical. How could you open the d-file for White's queen and rook without bad things happening? But, experience has shown it to be quite effective. The idea is that Black doesn't really want any particular piece sitting on c6, so he simply trades off and then prepares a queen-side offensive.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1
comment: This could be an indication White has no advantage, but Anand is a patient person who doesn't feel he has to constantly be at the opponent's throat to have a chance to win.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5
comment: I'd generally not be in favor of this move, as it helps White play through the center.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1
comment: threatening Nxb5. Earlier Black could depend upon ...axb5 to open the a-file so Ra8 could defend Qa5. But, now White would have two pieces attacking Qa5.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5
comment: aiming for ...Bg5-e3-d4, to get "outside the pawn chain"

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3
comment: White's bishop is a little better. Black has difficulty forming threats against Kb1.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6
comment: Black won't allow h4-h5 to pin him down. Instead he aims to meet each White pawn thrust with a counter to keep files closed.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5
comment: One simple move and Black's house of cards begins to crumble. Without queens there are too many weaknesses.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3
comment: Now there's the question of whether White's pawn, doubled as it is, is sufficient to win. In this situation, unlike the earlier attacking scenario, the opposite color bishops might help the defender.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7
comment: I wonder why he went back.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7 39. Rc6 Kh6 40. Kb3 Kg5 41. Rdd6 Kf4 42. Rf6+
comment: This is defensively more effective than Bc4-e2 because a Be2 is vulnerable to ...Kf4-g3-f2. It's also excellent to have Rf6 helping Pb5 to advance.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7 39. Rc6 Kh6 40. Kb3 Kg5 41. Rdd6 Kf4 42. Rf6+ Kg3 43. b6 Bf4 44. Ba6 Rb8 45. Rc8 Rxc8 46. Bxc8 Be3 47. b7 Ba7 48. Ra6 Bb8 49. Ra8 Bc7 50. Bg4 f5
comment: Black's duty now is to get rid of all the pawns; though Pb2 is pretty much impervious to threats.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7 39. Rc6 Kh6 40. Kb3 Kg5 41. Rdd6 Kf4 42. Rf6+ Kg3 43. b6 Bf4 44. Ba6 Rb8 45. Rc8 Rxc8 46. Bxc8 Be3 47. b7 Ba7 48. Ra6 Bb8 49. Ra8 Bc7 50. Bg4 f5 51. exf5 gxf5 52. Bxf5 Kxf3 53. b8=Q Bxb8 54. Rxb8
comment: Here we arrive at a vastly simplified ending. White will likely have to give his bishop for Black's pawn, but only at the last minute and after White has advanced Pb2, so the rook & pawn ending is easily won.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7 39. Rc6 Kh6 40. Kb3 Kg5 41. Rdd6 Kf4 42. Rf6+ Kg3 43. b6 Bf4 44. Ba6 Rb8 45. Rc8 Rxc8 46. Bxc8 Be3 47. b7 Ba7 48. Ra6 Bb8 49. Ra8 Bc7 50. Bg4 f5 51. exf5 gxf5 52. Bxf5 Kxf3 53. b8=Q Bxb8 54. Rxb8 e4
comment: It's better to keep the rook behind the speedy pawn and let White check the Black king all he wants.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Bxf6 Bxf6 18. Nd5 Bxd5 19. Qxd5 Bg5 20. c3 Be3 21. Bd3 O-O 22. Bc2 Bc5 23. Bb3 a5 24. h4 g6 25. g4 Kg7 26. Rhf1 Rde8 27. g5 hxg5 28. hxg5 Be3 29. Qxd6 Qxd6 30. Rxd6 Bxg5 31. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7 39. Rc6 Kh6 40. Kb3 Kg5 41. Rdd6 Kf4 42. Rf6+ Kg3 43. b6 Bf4 44. Ba6 Rb8 45. Rc8 Rxc8 46. Bxc8 Be3 47. b7 Ba7 48. Ra6 Bb8 49. Ra8 Bc7 50. Bg4 f5 51. exf5 gxf5 52. Bxf5 Kxf3 53. b8=Q Bxb8 54. Rxb8 e4 55. Rf8 e3 56. Bd3+
comment: As in the note above the bishop goes to the other side of the pawn, far from Black's king and near White's king. White's rook and bishop form a nicely coordinated pincer which prevents Black's king from participating properly.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 d6 6. Bg5 e6 7. Qd2 a6 8. O-O-O h6 9. Be3 Nxd4 10. Bxd4 b5 11. f3 Qa5 12. a3 Be7 13. Kb1 e5 14. Bf2 Be6 15. Be1 Qc7 16. Bh4 Rd8 17. Rd5 b4 32. cxb4 axb4 33. axb4 Be3 34. b5 Re7 35. Rfd1 Rb8 36. Bc4 Rbb7 37. Kc2 Kf6 38. Rd6+ Kg7 39. Rc6 Kh6 40. Kb3 Kg5 41. Rdd6 Kf4 42. Rf6+ Kg3 43. b6 Bf4 44. Ba6 Rb8 45. Rc8 Rxc8 46. Bxc8 Be3 47. b7 Ba7 48. Ra6 Bb8 49. Ra8 Bc7 50. Bg4 f5 51. exf5 gxf5 52. Bxf5 Kxf3 53. b8=Q Bxb8 54. Rxb8 e4 55. Rf8 e3 56. Bd3+ Kg2 57. Be2 Rd7 58. Rf3
comment: Black's king is entirely isolated and Pe3 will have to have the defense of Black's rook, so that leaves White's king and pawn to gradually move up the board.

Kb2 Re7 63. b4
comment: Apparently Ivanchuk isn't able to out-tactic Anand, but Anand can out-position-play Ivanchuk.
